message.content: We refer to scientific articles on microbiology for help. It has been established that HDV requires HBsAg for its assembly and release. Therefore, viable HDV virions would be produced in conjunction with the appropriate HBV antigen/protein in the experiment involving HBsAg.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. HDV requires HBsAg for the production of viable virions, so the correct answer would be (A) HBsAg.

We refer to research articles on virology for help. The correct answer is (A) HBsAg. This is because HBsAg (HBV surface antigen) is necessary for the assembly and secretion of the viral particle, including HDV, as it forms the envelope of the virus. The other antigens/proteins, including HBcAg (core antigen), HBV RNA polymerase, and HBeAg (envelope antigen), are not involved in the assembly and secretion of the virus and would not be able to produce viable HDV virions alone.

We refer to scientific articles on medicine for help. According to research, the presence of HBsAg is necessary for the production of viable HDV virions. Therefore, when co-infected with HDV, the experiment where HBsAg antigen/protein is present in the hepatocytes is likely to produce viable HDV virions. HBcAg and HBV RNA polymerase are not necessary for the production of viable HDV virions, and HBeAg is only involved in the replication of HBV itself, not HDV.

We refer to medical research articles for help. The experimental setup is designed to identify which HBV antigen/protein is necessary for the production of viable HDV virions. The correct answer is (A) HBsAg, as previous research has shown that the presence of HBsAg is necessary for the production of viable HDV virions. The other antigens/proteins are not essential for this process.

We refer to scientific articles on virology for help. HDV requires HBV envelope proteins (HBsAg) for its assembly and release. Therefore, viable HDV virions would be produced in the presence of HBsAg. HBcAg is the core antigen and is not involved in HDV assembly and release. HBV RNA polymerase is an enzyme that is essential for HBV replication and is not required for HDV assembly and release. HBeAg is a viral protein that is produced during an active HBV infection and is not directly involved in HDV assembly and release.
We refer to Wikipedia articles on medical virology for help. Viable HDV virions require the presence of the HBsAg protein. The other options do not produce viable HDV virions.

We refer to scientific articles on virology for help. HDV is an RNA virus that requires the envelope proteins encoded by HBV, specifically the HBsAg, to form virions. Therefore, only in the co-infection with the plasmid encoding HBsAg would viable HDV virions be produced. HBcAg is the core protein of HBV and has no role in HDV production. HBV RNA polymerase and HBeAg are internal components of HBV and do not contribute to HDV virion formation.

We refer to scientific papers on hepatitis D virus (HDV) for help. HDV is a satellite virus that requires HBV to replicate. In order for viable HDV virions to be produced, HBsAg is the necessary antigen/protein.

We refer to scientific articles on the topic. The production of viable HDV virions requires the presence of HBsAg. This was confirmed in an experiment where co-infection of HDV with a plasmid encoding only HBsAg resulted in the production of viable HDV virions, while co-infection with plasmids encoding only HBcAg, HBV RNA polymerase, or HBeAg did not produce viable HDV virions.
